TEI.2.document_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1922: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1928), 3 vols., Vol 2, pp. 1116

barker_notes.barker_summary: Humphrey Jackson's memorandum concerning the case of the Mary, June 4, 1825.
barker_notes.barker_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1919: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1924), 3 vols., Vol 1, Part 2, pp. 1116

text.body:
*div1 type="summary"* *p*Humphrey Jackson's memorandum concerning the case of the Mary, June 4, 1825.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p*Memo, from *person_mentioned*H Jackson relative*/person_mentioned* to *person_mentioned*Carrico */person_mentioned*when *person_mentioned*Nelson */person_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*Cartwright */person_mentioned*applied for a process *person_mentioned*J.*/person_mentioned* went down to*location_mentioned* *person_mentioned*Hunter*/person_mentioned*s*/location_mentioned* to see *person_mentioned*Carrico*/person_mentioned* and *person_mentioned*Allen */person_mentioned*and try and compromise—*person_mentioned*Allen */person_mentioned*agreed that they were liable for the things lost but contended that they ought only to pay the *location_mentioned*Orleans */location_mentioned*price—and finally the *person_mentioned*parties */person_mentioned*went *location_mentioned*on board the Mary*/location_mentioned* to receive as much property as would secure *person_mentioned*N.*/person_mentioned* and *person_mentioned*C.*/person_mentioned* leaving it for future determination at what price the lost property should be rated at but when they reached the mary *person_mentioned*C.*/person_mentioned* and*person_mentioned* A.*/person_mentioned* told them that if they got any thing it must be by law and refused to come to any settle- ment—afterwards they agreed to pay for the Goods at the *location_mentioned*Orleans*/location_mentioned* price.—The Mary was aground *location_mentioned*on red fish bar*/location_mentioned* when she was attached and was got off by the assistance of the *person_mentioned*Constable */person_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*guard*/person_mentioned* and run on by *person_mentioned*Carrico */person_mentioned*in trying to bring her *location_mentioned*into the San Jacinto*/location_mentioned*— the *person_mentioned*Alcalde */person_mentioned*demanded before tryal wheither they had any objection to any of the *person_mentioned*Jury */person_mentioned*and furnished them with a list, and stated that if they had any objection others would be summoned on the morning of the tryal they agreed that they were liable for the property lost but only differd as to the price, so that the only thing for the *person_mentioned*Jury*/person_mentioned* to decide was the price of the property.*/p*
*/div1*
